image.altText: Aerial shot of dozens of houses in neat rows in a new outer-suburban housing estate.

props.synopsis: More than one in four residential properties purchased in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland last year were paid for entirely with cash by older Australians, highlighting the growing disparity in the property market.

title.children: $129 billion of property was purchased in Australia's biggest states last year without a mortgage

image.altText: A man and a woman looking serious standing next to a wall

props.synopsis: Their home was supposed to be Kim and Keven's retirement dream, but they say the build was riddled with issues, significantly delayed, and they kept hitting walls trying to get problems fixed.Â

title.children: From a leaking bathroom to safety hazards, couple fights to have issues fixed in $1m newly built dream retirement home

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Raymond Shaw says he has spent the past five-and-a-half weeks uncovering and exploring disused mine shafts in a determined effort to find anything that helps locate the Ballarat mum.

title.children: There are countless mineshafts in the area being searched for signs of Samantha Murphy. This is what it's like inside them

image.altText: Sun in an orange sky overlooking a wharf

props.synopsis: After a hot and humid summer, NSW is now enduring an extended spell of warm autumn weather moving into its second week.

title.children: Sydney's waters now warm enough for a tropical cyclone

image.altText: The drug ice sitting on a bench top.

props.synopsis: Australia's alcohol consumption is in decline while the use of other drugs such as methamphetamines, cocaine and MDMA is growing, according to new wastewater analysis.

title.children: Meth up, booze down: What wastewater testing tells us about Australia's drug use

image.altText: A truck dumps a load of tomatoes.

props.synopsis: Fresh produce growers scramble to meet "forecast" supply deals with supermarkets, but every year millions of dollars of surplus food goes to waste. So what's going on?

title.children: Fruit, veg growers say biggest customer 'is the rubbish bin', as millions of tonnes of food is wasted

image.altText: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang dressed in suits stand inside a room.

props.synopsis: As China's annual rubberstamp parliament comes to a close, there are still looming questions about whether policymakers are doing enough to tackle the country's economic malaise, writes Kathleen Calderwood.

title.children: 'Not good': Beijing insists everything is fine. Here's what real people say about China's economic situation

image.altText: Two soldiers, with their backs to a camera, operating a large machine outdoors with flames coming out of it

props.synopsis: A former Ukrainian MP urges Australia to provide more support to the country's war effort, after the efficacy of a deal struck with France last year to provide shells to the country's military comes under the microscope.Â Â

title.children: One day's worth of shells: Inside Australia's 'slipping' support for Ukraine

image.altText: A koala with bandaged paws sits in the crook of a tree branch within a recovery facility

props.synopsis: Climate change and bushfires are forcing massive changes to the way Australia conserves threatened animals and plants.

title.children: How the plan to manage threatened species has evolved since Black Summer

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: It comes after a judicial review found communications between a journalist and the head of the inquiry, Walter Sofronoff, could lead a fair-minded observer to conclude the reporterÂ impacted Mr Sofronoff's views.

title.children: Former ACT top prosecutor wants the government to redact parts of the report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Reds players recover in the heat during

props.synopsis: After a weekend where extreme heat delayed major league games, there is no question anymore about the impact climate change has on sport. But a new report by an organisation of athletes has found most major sporting bodies have so far stayed silent on the issue.Â

title.children: The sports we love face a massive threat, and some of the big Aussie codes don't have a game plan

image.altText: wine bottles

props.synopsis: Beijing appears to be just weeks away from removing tariffs that have crippled Australia's wine industry since 2020, with an interim decision by China's authorities reporting that the duties are no longer necessary.

title.children: China's wine report finds tariffs not necessary as final decision expected by March 31

image.altText: An aerial shot of a mass of reddish-brown water in an outback landscape.

props.synopsis: Police have "urgent welfare concerns" for three elderly people and four children who are missing in WA's flooded outback.

title.children: 'Too dangerous': Search postponed for seven people, including four children, lost in WA floods

image.altText: Two people looking at a smartphone, a younger person pointing out the screen to an elderly woman

props.synopsis: There are promising signs a crackdown is working, however Australians were fleeced of just under half a billion dollars last year, according to new ACCC Scamwatch figures.

title.children: Fake ads on the rise as scams on social media claim more older victims

image.altText: Kylie Minogue, in a white dress with white microphone, on stage, signing with her eyes closed

props.synopsis: Rev up the group chat and start booking your mid-winter road trip to Byron because your Splendour In The Grass line-up is here!

title.children: Kylie Minogue headlining stacked Splendour In The Grass line-up

image.altText: A large truck

props.synopsis: Yarra City Council will investigate raising the cost of parking a larger vehicle on its streets, citing safety concerns.Â

title.children: 'Buy yourself a Hummer, you're an absolute idiot': Inner-Melbourne council debates parking hike for big cars

image.altText: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence skills are increasingly in demand, with the number of job ads requiring AI skills surging 21-fold in the past year. LinkedIn's chief economist reveals which jobs are likely to be disrupted by AIÂ â for better or worse.

title.children: Rise of artificial intelligence could cut wages of workers who don't 'upskill' as AI job ads surge

image.altText: A composite image of Brisbane Broncos' Ezra Mam and Sydney Roosters' Spencer Leniu during their NRL season opener in Las Vegas.

props.synopsis: While much of rugby league world spent the last week squabbling over whether Spencer Leniu calling Ezra Mam a "monkey" was a racist slur or just banter, there was a collective eye roll from many First Nations people.

title.children: Why Spencer Leniu's 'monkey' slur was more than 'one brown man sledging another brown man'

image.altText: A child hands a bottle of baby formula milk to a two-year-old.

props.synopsis: It's the ultra-processed milk powder intentionally marketed as a follow-on to breastfeeding or infant formulae. But the evidence suggests toddler or transition milks are unnecessary at best and harmful at worst.

title.children: 'Hoodwinked and fooled': How Australian parents are being misled on toddler milk

image.altText: Individual pictures of five teenagers' faces on a colourful background with a sign reading "uni options" and picture of a plane.

props.synopsis: From creating a national "jobs broker" to raising income support, potential changes could open a world of educational possibilities for rural students.

title.children: Will university reforms help more young people chase their dreams?

image.altText: Man, woman and child kneeling on ground with man holding up a large python.

props.synopsis: What precautions can you take to make your property as unappealing to snakes as possible â and what should you do if you do spot one? We ask the experts.

title.children: What you should and shouldn't do if you see or hear a snake in your home or yard

image.altText: Students sit with their teacher in a classroom

props.synopsis: The federal government will invest an additional $737 million from 2025 to 2029 in Northern Territory public schools under the agreement, which it says will go to addressing serious educational disadvantage in the territory.

title.children: Federal and NT governments announce $1b package to fully fund NT public schools

image.altText: A white van carrying Armaguard's badge logo stationary in a parking lot.

props.synopsis: The big four banks are poised to intervene in the business of transporting cash because its plummeting use is making it unprofitable for Armaguard to deliver.

title.children: Declining cash use threatening nation's money mover Armaguard

image.altText: Admiral Jonathan Mead watches a Virginia-class submarine on the water.

props.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles insists AUKUS partners are working "at pace" to help Australia acquire nuclear-powered submarines after the United States revealed it would halve next year's planned production of Virginia-class boats.

title.children: Turnbull says Australians 'mugged by AUKUS reality' as US plans to halve submarine production

image.altText: A woman smiles and poses for a photo

props.synopsis: A pair charged over an alleged kidnapping and assault of a man in Melbourne last month have been named as Laura Allam and Mohammad Sharab after a suppression order was partially lifted.

title.children: Human rights activist charged over alleged kidnapping and assault of a man in Melbourne

image.altText: Close up of Andrew Tate wearing a tweed blazer

props.synopsis: A Romanian court approves a request to extradite internet personality Andrew Tate to the UK where he will face allegations of sexual aggression, but only after his trial in Romania is complete.

title.children: Romanian court approves request to extradite online influencer Andrew Tate to UK

image.altText: A vessel on the water currying supplies.

props.synopsis: A ship carrying food leaves a port in Cyprus for Gaza as part of a pilot project to open a new sea route for aid to a population on the brink of famine.

title.children: First aid ship leaves Cyprus bound for Gaza in bid to establish 'maritime highway'

image.altText: Woman pray shoulder to shoulder in a mosque

props.synopsis: Millions of Muslims come together to mark the start of the holy month of Ramadan across South-East Asia â a time when prayer, fasting and celebration dominate daily life.

title.children: Millions of Muslims begin holy month of Ramadan across the Asia-Pacific

image.altText: pig

props.synopsis: Politicians who stayed for the footage from a Stanhope piggery, including the alleged bestiality of a pig by a worker, watched on in shock as it was played to them at the parliamentary Inquiry into Pig Welfare in Victoria.

title.children: MPs at inquiry refuse to watch footage of Victorian piggery, including vision of alleged bestiality

image.altText: Four rainbow lorikeets in little towel beds being nursed.

props.synopsis: The ailment, known as lorikeet paralysis syndrome, spread rapidly through south-east Queensland rainbow lorikeet populations earlier this year.

title.children: Rainbow lorikeets released after recovering from paralysis syndrome that causes them to fall from the sky
